body: Another idea would be to remove generic maths completely from `std` and leave it up to to client libs to implement. I'm not sure how prevalent usage of generic maths is in `std` however. I realise that would be a complete reversal of my work in #4819 however.
Of course some traits would still be left - I'm mainly talking about the math functions.
Nominating.

I'm actually starting to think we should just zap the traits entirely (yay, back to the beginning!), and bring on the fragmentation! We still don't know how best to use traits yet, so maybe it would be better to leave that up to the community.
Accepted for 1.0, P-backcompat-libs

I'm now working on what I hope to become something like `extra::num` in this repository: https://github.com/bjz/num-rs

What I'm planning is to do is make `std::num` very naive and tied to the base numeric types, but then have `extra::num` founded in reasonably good mathematical concepts. That would avoid the ugly compromise we've made in the current `std::num`.

How does this sound?
oo, i like this stuff. prevent lockin while making is sane to experiment. :+1:

Is this reverting what was started with #4819?
If yes, for the future: what where the problems?

Yes. The API that resulted from #4819 attempted, like Haskell, to blend both the primitive numerics and higher level mathematical concepts into one API. This resulted in an ugly hybrid where neither goal was adequately met. I think the libstd should have a strong focus on implementing fundamental operations for the base numeric types, but no more. Leave the higher level concepts to libnum or future community projects.

It seems to me that the methods that are valid for complex numbers (and in general normed division algebras) should be split out in a separate trait from the ones that also requires a total order, so that it is possible to write code that works for both real and complex numbers.

For example, `exp` is valid for complex numbers, but `floor` isn't.

yes, certain floating point operations make sense only for real float, complex float, and some make sense for both. And this should be recognized

BUT, these float classes should not be conflated with being proper numerical classes, that way lies sadness and madness.

In my head, I see floating point trait as pretty monolithic, driven specifically by the IEEE-754 spec. Other libs could delegate to the floating point implementations, wrapping it in a more fine-grained API, depending on the domain.
yes, agreed. I think bill was just remarking the IEEE Real Floats have a different api than Complex Floats

The problem of that is that code will be written using the Float trait and will not be usable on other types, even though it would totally make sense.

For example, if you write a function to solve second degree equations, then you need an `sqrt`, which is provided by the Float trait, so it would be written using that.

However then you can't use it to solve second degree equations with complex numbers, even though the code is of course the same.

libm has functions like cexp and csqrt that should be accessible using the same interface that abstracts exp and expf.
Again, libs would be able wrap the IEEE implementations if they wanted a more specialized API. There would be no need to use the IEEE trait directly if a user was using one of those libs.

yes. This should _JUST_ be for IEEE Float types, and it should very very clear "if  you want more generic code, helps us write a layer on top". Modeling generic mathy types and modelling floating types are not the same thing. ever. Floats are not algebraic reals, they are not constructive reals, etc etc. Conflating "heres an api just for floats" and "good numerical types api" is bad.
Yeah, I think it should be up to the client library author whether they want to use floats as if they were reals. We shouldn't try to do this in the std though.
yeah. using floats as if they're reals requires really precisely understanding how floats _arent_ reals.
@bjz What's left on this?
We could merge `Round` into `Float` and `Bitwise` into `Int` (possibly renaming to `Integer`).
@bjz What's left on this now?

As a heads-up: as part of library stabilization, I am now working on removing all the numerics traits (as per [@bjz's comment above](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/10387#issuecomment-31810793). These traits are currently providing little value in `std`, and we're better served by a library of traits and implementations in the Cargo ecosystem.
After some discussion with @alexcrichton, it looks like this is probably an RFC-worthy change. I will write an RFC in the near future and link to it from here.
Nice! Are there going to be any issues in providing polymorphic functions in the bundled libraries though?

@bjz The RFC will likely keep `Int` and `Float` traits. Methods on primitive int and float types have to be added via extension traits anyway, and since the API is identical across various sizes having a single trait makes sense. I'm still working out the precise details, though.
Can we remove them from the prelude? _looks hopefully_

If we don't have them in the prelude, the various int/float methods they define won't be available by default (you'd have to import the traits). But these are pretty specialized methods, so that might be OK.

What's are the drawbacks you see to having these in the prelude?
RFC here: https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/369
@bjz I think we can close this now, agreed?
Closed :)
